p: Furthermore, the high anti-microbiological activity of the oregano oil is connected with the high concentration of terpenoids, carvacrol in particular [ 17, 18, 34]. However, the tested commercial oregano oil did not contain carvacrol, but only thymol (11%), p-thymol (33%), and limonene (15.5%). Most probably, it was these compounds present in high concentrations that were responsible for the inhibition of E. coli. The oil obtained in the process of maceration, despite the fact it contained carvacrol (1.8%) and thymol (2.5%), probably did not reveal any biological activity due to the low concentrations of these compounds.
